Paulius Dilkas

I am a PhD student jointly at the University of Edinburgh (Artificial Intelligence and its Applications Institute, School of Informatics) and Heriot-Watt University. My work is supervised by Vaishak Belle and funded by the Edinburgh Centre for Robotics via a scholarship from the EPSRC Centre for Doctoral Training in Robotics and Autonomous Systems. I received my MSci in Computing Science degree from the University of Glasgow.

I work on both theoretical and empirical aspects of inference for probabilistic relational and graphical models (e.g., Bayesian networks, probabilistic logic programming languages, weighted model counting). Previously, I have worked on graph algorithms, algorithm portfolios, formal modelling with bigraphs, and inverse reinforcement learning. More generally, I am interested in a variety of problems at the intersection of artificial intelligence and theoretical computer science (especially algorithmics).

p.dilkas@sms.ed.ac.uk

Teaching

2019-now
At the School of Informatics, University of Edinburgh, I worked on the following courses:
  • Discrete Mathematics and Mathematical Reasoning (2nd year course, tutor)
  • Introduction to Algorithms and Data Structures (2nd year course, tutor)
  • Introduction to Computation (1st year course, tutor)
  • Introduction to Software Engineering (2nd year course, marker)
  • Object Oriented Programming (2nd year course, demonstrator, marker)
2017-2019
At the School of Computing Science, University of Glasgow I worked as a demonstrator for the following courses:
  • Artificial Intelligence (4th year course)
  • Programming (1st year course)
  • Systems Programming (3rd year course)
2012-2017
Before that, I worked as a Distance Learning Teacher in Mathematics at the National Student Academy in Lithuania
